Situation1: They support a mentee facing a high-stakes project that could determine their future career trajectory.
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the clock ticking louder with every passing minute. My phone buzzed with a message from my mentee, Sarah, who was anxiously awaiting my feedback on her proposal for the hospital’s new patient care initiative. She was on the verge of a breakthrough, and I knew my encouragement could make all the difference in her confidence and career. At the same time, my pager vibrated with an urgent alert: Mr. Patel, my patient with a complex autoimmune disorder, was experiencing a flare-up. His treatment plan was intricate, and any delay in adjusting his medications could have serious consequences.

As a mentor, I felt the weight of Sarah’s trust in me, her hope that I would guide her to success. As a doctor, I was responsible for Mr. Patel’s health, knowing that my expertise could ease his suffering. The demands pulled at me from both sides—Sarah’s future and Mr. Patel’s present. My mind raced, torn between nurturing growth and providing care, both expecting my full attention. I stared at the two messages, heart pounding, caught in the impossible space between who I am to others and who I need to be right now.
